Thus $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ is the $n$-category generated by two objects which we will continue to called $X$ and $Y$, two 1-morphisms $f: X \rightarrow Y$ and $g: Y \rightarrow X$, two 2 -morphisms $f g \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ and $\mathrm{id}_{Y} \rightarrow f g$, two 3 -morphisms, and so on, ending with two $n$-morphisms and one equation between $n$-morphisms (of the form $\alpha \beta=\mathrm{id}$ ). Note that this list was just the list of generators, not the full list of $k$-morphisms in $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$.
Remark 2.1.3. Higher categories like $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ freely generated by some pasting diagram are sometimes called "computads" in the higher category theory literature, or " $n$-computads" when one wants to emphasize the category number. They will exist in any model of $n$-categories: if one cannot present an $n$-category by a pasting diagram, then one's notion of " $n$-category" is clearly deficient. Indeed, the ability to present $n$-categories by pasting diagrams is the fundamental axiom used in [BSP11].

Just like our $n$-categories, our $n$-computads are always weak. One must be a bit cautious when working with $n$-computads because of this weakness. Consider, for example, the free 3 -category with a single object $\bullet$, no nonidentity 1-morphisms, and one generating 2 -morphism $x: \mathrm{id}_{\bullet} \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{\bullet}$. Up to isomorphism, the complete list of 2 -morphisms in this category consists of the powers of $x$. But there are many 3 -morphisms, all invertible, parameterizing the ways that the 2 -morphism $x$ can braid around itself. For a related caution, see [Che13].
Remark 2.1.4. Any $(n+1)$-category $\mathcal{C}$ has an $n$-localization $\lambda_{\leq n} \mathcal{C}$ in which the $(n+1)$-morphisms are forced to be identities; $\lambda_{\leq n}$ is by definition the left adjoint to the inclusion $\mathbf{C a t}_{n} \hookrightarrow \mathbf{C a t}_{n+1}$. From their presentations, it is clear that $\lambda_{\leq n} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n+1}=\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. (As with elsewhere in this paper, the " $=$ " sign means that there is a canonical equivalence.) In particular, for any $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$, an $n$-condensation in $\mathcal{C}$ is the same as an $(n+1)$-condensation in $\mathcal{C}$-thought-of-as-an- $(n+1)$-category.

Whereas one should expect that all reasonable models of "weak $n$-category" will be equivalent for finite $n$, there are at least two truly inequivalent versions of "weak $\infty$-category" [SPRJF]. (It is unfortunate that the term " $\infty$-category" has come to mean something with only one dimension of noninvertibility. We will stubbornly continue to call the latter " $(\infty, 1)$-categories," so that "[weak] $\infty$-category" can mean some model-independent notion of the $n \rightarrow \infty$ limit of "[weak] $n$-category," or in other words " $(\infty, \infty)$-category.") In the inductive version, a weak $\infty$-category is determined by all the ways to map into it from weak $n$-categories for finite $n$. In the coinductive version, a weak $\infty$-category is determined by all the ways to map from it to weak $n$-categories for finite $n$. One can test the difference as follows: for coinductive $\infty$-categories, infinite dualizability is the same as invertibility, since these notions become the same after truncating to any finite $n$; for inductive $\infty$-categories, infinite dualizability is weaker than invertibility.

The limit $\boldsymbol{\Delta}:=\underline{\lim } \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ along the canonical maps $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n+1} \rightarrow \lambda_{\leq n} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n+1}=\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ is most naturally interpreted as a coinductive $\infty$-category. It can also be presented inductively as a certain free $\infty$-category generated by two cells of each dimension. By construction, $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ has the property that if $\mathcal{C}$ is an $n$-category for $n<\infty$, then the functors from $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ to $\mathcal{C}$, i.e. the diagrams in $\mathcal{C}$ of shape $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$, are the same as those from $\lambda_{\leq n} \boldsymbol{\Delta}=\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. Thus, by talking in terms of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$, we can work with $n$-condensations for all $n$ simultaneously. We will refer to $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ as the walking ( $\infty$-)condensation. We emphasize that this is simply a matter of linguistics: $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ is defined by its maps to finite- $n$-categories, which are defined to be $n$-condensations.

Remark 2.1.5. Let $I=\{\bullet \rightarrow \bullet\}$ denote the walking arrow, so that the morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$ are the diagrams of shape $I$. Then a commuting square in $\mathcal{C}$ is nothing but a diagram of shape $I^{2}$. The product of $n$-categories is computed "levelwise" in the following sense: the $k$-morphisms in a product are simply the product of $k$-morphisms. (Indeed, the functor $\mathcal{C} \mapsto\{k$-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}\}$ is representable by the walking $k$-morphism; compare [JFS17, Definition 3.3].) For instance, $I$ has, up to isomorphism, a total of two 0 -morphisms and three 1-morphisms, including identities, and so $I^{2}$ has four 0 -morphisms and nine 1-morphisms, including identities and compositions.

Similarly, we define a commuting condensation square to be a diagram in $\mathcal{C}$ of shape $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{2}$, and more generally a commuting condensation $k$-cube is a diagram of shape $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{k}$ :
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

In particular, in $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{2}$, the four sides of the square $\left(X, Y_{1}, f_{1}, g_{1}, \ldots\right),\left(X, Y_{2}, f_{2}, g_{2}, \ldots\right),\left(Y_{1}, Z, p_{1}, q_{1}, \ldots\right)$, and $\left(Y_{2}, Z, p_{2}, q_{2}, \ldots\right)$ are all condensations, and all the subsquares commute, so that, for example, there are isomorphisms $p_{1} f_{1} \cong p_{2} f_{2}, g_{1} q_{1} \cong g_{2} q_{2}, f_{2} g_{1} \cong q_{2} p_{1}$, and $f_{1} g_{2} \cong q_{1} p_{2}$. It is worth emphasizing that in higher categories, commutativity is data, not property: to give a commuting square, one must give these isomorphisms. This it not the end of the commutativity data: there are also commutativity isomorphisms indexed by products of higher cells in $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{2}$, indicated by the " $[\cdots]$."

A commuting condensation square $\left(X, Y_{1}, Y_{2}, Z, \ldots\right)$ includes a diagonal condensation $X \rightarrow Z$ given by pulling back a diagram $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{2} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ along the diagonal inclusion $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \hookrightarrow \boldsymbol{\Delta}^{2}$.
2.2. Condensation monads. The main result underlying the ordinary Karoubi envelope construction is that a 1-condensation $(f, g): X \rightarrow Y$ is uniquely determined by the composition

$e:=g f \in \operatorname{hom}(X, X)$. This map $e$ is an idempotent $-e^{2}=e-$ and a 1-category is Karoubi complete if all idempotents factor through (automatically unique) condensations. We must categorify the notion of idempotent.

To do so, we study the composition $e:=g f$ in the walking $n$-condensation $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. One can think of $e$ either as a 1-morphism $e: X \rightarrow X$ or as an object of the monoidal $(n-1)$-category $\operatorname{End}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}}(X)$. Up to isomorphism, the objects of the latter are precisely the powers of $e$. Let us write $\phi: f g \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ and $\gamma: \operatorname{id}_{Y} \rightarrow f g$ for the 2 -morphisms that are part of the condensation $f g \rightarrow \operatorname{id}_{Y}$. The equation $e^{2}=e$ in the 1 -category case categorifies to a condensation

$$
e^{2}=(g f)(g f)=g(f g) f \rightarrow g \operatorname{id}_{Y} f=g f=e
$$

in $\operatorname{End}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}}(X)$ with "downward" arrow $g . \phi . f$ and "upward" arrow $g . \gamma . f$. Note that the "equalities" in the above equation are really applications of the monoidality data in $\operatorname{End}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}}(X)$. A condensation includes morphisms in both directions, and in the case of the condensation $e^{2} \rightarrow e$, these can be thought of as a binary operation and a binary co-operation on $e$, making $e$ into a sort of (bi)algebra object.

In a monoidal 1-category $\mathcal{D}$, a binary operation mult : $A^{2} \rightarrow A$ on an object $A \in \mathcal{D}$ is associative when the square
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
commutes. (As above, we have suppressed the monoidality data of $\mathcal{D}$ from the diagram.) The binary operation $g . \phi . f: e^{2} \rightarrow e$ that we have identified indeed provides such a commuting square, as the two sides of
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
are both equal to $g . \phi . \phi . f$.
In higher categories, commutativity of squares is data. In this case, the data involves the "interchange" or "functoriality" law for horizontal composition. Associativity of a binary operation $m: A^{2} \rightarrow A$ also involves higher data, for example a pentagonator that relates various applications of associativity between the available maps $A^{4} \rightarrow A$. There is a relatively easy way to parameterize these data. Specifically, for each $k \in \mathbb{N}$, one must give a commuting $k$-dimensional cube with "top" vertex $A^{k+1}$, "bottom" vertex $A$, and intermediate vertices labeled by intermediate powers of $A$; let's call it the $k$-dimensional associcube. Most faces of associcubes are lower-dimensional associcubes, perhaps with some whiskering by $A$ (just as in the above 2-dimensional cube, the top two edges are the 1-dimensional cube $m: A^{2} \rightarrow A$ with some whiskering, and the bottom two edges are unwhiskered). Some faces are, modulo associativity data of the ambient category $\mathcal{D}$, simply identities. For example, one of the six faces of the three-dimensional associcube is filled in by the canonical equivalence $(A . m) \circ\left(m . A^{2}\right)=m . m=(m . A) \circ\left(A^{2} \cdot m\right): A^{4} \rightarrow A^{2}$; depending on one's model for higher monoidal categories, this canonical equivalence involves various

interchange/functoriality laws. These "identity" faces are usually collapsed, and the well-known associahedra arise as cross-sections of the collapsed associcubes.

Let us return to the endomorphism $e=g f$ in $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$, and temporarily set $n=2$. In addition to the binary operation $g . \phi . f$ there was also a co-operation $g . \gamma . f$ coming from the upward part of $e^{2} \rightarrow e$. This co-operation is coassociative for the same reason that the binary operation was associative. Moreover, the following squares commute:
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

These precisely say that $e$ is not just a (nonunital) associative algebra and a (noncounital) coassociative coalgebra, but in fact a Frobenius algebra. That the comultiplication splits the multiplication makes it into a special Frobenius algebra. We will go into more detail on this case in Example 3.0.1.

Together with the specialness, the four Frobenius algebra axioms - associativity, coassociativity, and the two Frobenius identities - can be succinctly encoded by saying that there is a commuting condensation square (in the sense of Remark 2.1.5) with the following vertices:
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

The lower sides are of course the same condensation $e^{2} \rightarrow e$, and the upper sides are the two whiskerings of this condensation by $e$. Now allowing $n$ to be arbitrary, we axiomatize this structure:

Definition 2.2.1. A condensation algebra in a monoidal $(n-1)$-category is a sequence of commuting condensation cubes
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)
in which the faces the $k$-dimensional cube are either whiskerings of lower-dimensional cubes or are identities, following exactly the combinatorics of the associacubes recalled earlier.
$A$ condensation monad in an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is an object $X \in \mathcal{C}$ and a condensation algebra in the monoidal $(n-1)$-category $\operatorname{End}_{\mathcal{C}}(X)$. This follows the standard use of the term "monad" for "algebra object in an endomorphism category."

The walking condensation monad is the $n$-category $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ such that diagrams $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ are precisely condensation monads in $\mathcal{C}$. In other words, $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ can be presented by an object $X \in \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$, a 1-morphism $e: X \rightarrow X$, a condensation $e^{2} \rightarrow e$, a condensation square, $\ldots$

Note that for each $n, \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ is finitely presentable: just like ordinary cubes, condensation cubes of dimension $\gg n$ commute as soon as their faces do. As with the case of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ discussed in Remark 2.1.4, there is a canonical equivalence between the localization $\lambda_{\leq n} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n+1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$, justifying omitting the category number $n$ from the names "condensation algebra" and "condensation monad." Moreover,

we may talk about the $\infty$-category $\boldsymbol{\Delta}:=\underline{\lim } \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. Note that, as with $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$, this $\infty$-category is defined by the property that for any finite $n$, for any $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$, the functors $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ are precisely the functors $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

From the construction, there is a canonical functor $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ taking the sole object $X \in \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ to the object named $X \in \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. In an earlier version of this paper, we claimed that $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ was the full subcategory of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ on the object $X$, but our justification was insufficient. Instead, we formulate this as a conjecture:
$\operatorname{Conjecture}$ 2.2.2. $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ is the full subcategory of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ on the object $X$.
2.3. Constructing condensates. Having categorified the notions of split surjection (to condensation) and idempotent (to condensation monad), we may now categorify the property that all idempotents split:
Definition 2.3.1. The condensate of a condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots): \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, if it exists, is an extension to a condensation $(X \nrightarrow Y): \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$. An $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ has all condensates if all hom- $(n-1)$-categories $\operatorname{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(X, Y)$ in $\mathcal{C}$ have all condensates and furthermore every condensation monad $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ extends to a condensation $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

To justify Definition 2.3.1 (and in particular the use of the term "the" in the first sentence), we will show that condensates are unique if they exists. Note that a priori the condensates of $(X, e, \ldots)$ are the objects of an $n$-category $\operatorname{hom}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}, \mathcal{C}\right) \times_{\operatorname{hom}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}, \mathcal{C}\right)}\{\mathrm{pt}\}$, where $\{\mathrm{pt}\}$ denotes the terminal $n$-category, the map $\operatorname{hom}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}, \mathcal{C}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{hom}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}, \mathcal{C}\right)$ is restriction along the canonical inclusion, and $\{\mathrm{pt}\} \rightarrow \operatorname{hom}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}, \mathcal{C}\right)$ selects the condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots)$.
Theorem 2.3.2. Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is an $n$-category such that all hom- $(n-1)$-categories $\operatorname{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(X, Y)$ in $\mathcal{C}$ have all condensates, and let $(X, e, \ldots): \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ be a condensation monad in $\mathcal{C}$. Then the $n$-category of condensates $(X, e, \ldots)$ is either empty or contractible.

Our proof of Theorem 2.3.2 will occupy much of this section, and will be inductive in $n$. We briefly outline it here. We will first introduce notions of "condensation module" over a condensation algebra $e$ and of "tensor product" $\otimes_{e}$ of condensation modules. These notions are also the main ingredients in our higher Karoubi envelope construction, detailed in Theorem 2.3.11. By design, if $(X, Y, f, g, \ldots)$ is a condensation, then $f$ and $g$ will be modules for the condensation algebra $e=g f$. Suppose that $\left(X, Y_{1}, f_{1}, g_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X, Y_{2}, f_{2}, g_{2}, \ldots\right)$ are two condensations extending the same condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots)$. We want a canonical isomorphism $Y_{1} \cong Y_{2}$ compatible with the condensation data. We will complete the proof of Theorem 2.3.2 by showing that $f_{1} \otimes_{e} g_{2}: Y_{2} \rightarrow Y_{1}$ and $f_{2} \otimes_{e} g_{1}: Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{2}$ provide such an isomorphism.

To arrive at the definition of "condensation module," we build an $n$-category from two walking condensations $\left(X_{1}, Y_{1}, f_{1}, g_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X_{2}, Y_{2}, f_{2}, g_{2}, \ldots\right)$, together with a morphism $\mu: Y_{2} \rightarrow Y_{1}$. Set $m=g_{1} \mu f_{2}: X_{2} \rightarrow X_{1}$.
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Let us inspect the subcategory on the objects $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$. In addition to $m$, this category contains a condensation monad $e_{1}=g_{1} f_{1}: X_{1} \rightarrow X_{1}$ and a condensation monad $e_{2}=g_{2} f_{2}: X_{2} \rightarrow X_{2}$, and the full list of 1-morphisms consists of the powers of $e_{1}$, the powers of $e_{2}$, and the morphisms of the form $e_{1}^{i} m e_{2}^{j}$ for $i, j \geq 0$. There are also condensations $e_{1} m \nrightarrow m$ and $m e_{2} \nrightarrow m$, and more generally to identify various commuting condensation cubes relating them. Following the same logic that led to Definition 2.2.1 gives:

Definition 2.3.3. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $n$-category and $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X_{2}, e_{2}, \ldots\right)$ two condensation monads in $\mathcal{C}$. A condensation bimodule between them consists of a 1-morphism $m: X_{2} \rightarrow X_{1}$ and, for each pair $(i, j) \in \mathbb{N}^{2}$, an $(i+j)$-dimensional commuting condensation cube whose "top" vertex is $e_{1}^{i} m e_{2}^{j}$ and whose "bottom" vertex is $m$, and whose various faces are either whiskerings of lower dimensional cubes (including those that comprise the condensation monad structures on $e_{1}, e_{2}$ ) or identities:
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

The precise combinatorics specifying which faces are whiskerings and which are identities is the same as the combinatorics that axiomatize associative bimodules in terms of commuting cubes.

As with Conjecture 2.2.2, we believe but do not verify that this list of commuting condensation cubes presents the full subcategory of $(*)$ on the objects $X_{1}, X_{2}$.

Remark 2.3.4. Given condensation monads $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X_{2}, e_{2}, \ldots\right)$ in an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$, the $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodules are naturally the objects of an $(n-1)$-category whose (higher) morphisms deserve to be called condensation bimodule homomorphisms. Indeed, there is some $n$-category $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$, the "walking condensation bimodule," that parameterizes condensation bimodules, and it contains as a subcategory the disjoint union of two copies of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$; a condensation bimodule between $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X_{2}, e_{2}, \ldots\right)$ is an extension of the diagram $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}, \ldots\right) \sqcup\left(X_{2}, e_{2}, \ldots\right): \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}^{\cup 2} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ along $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}^{\cup 2} \hookrightarrow \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$, and a condensation bimodule homomorphism is a natural transformation of functors with domain $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ which restricts as the identity along $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}^{\cup 2} \hookrightarrow \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$. For fixed domain, the collection of functors and natural transformations into an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is naturally another $n$-category. In the case at hand, it drops to an $(n-1)$-category because the inclusion $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}^{\cup 2} \hookrightarrow \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{n}$ is essentially surjective.

Example 2.3.5. For any object $X^{\prime} \in \mathcal{C}$, there is an identity condensation monad $\left(X^{\prime}, \operatorname{id}_{X^{\prime}}, \ldots\right)$. A left module for a condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots)$ is a bimodule between $(X, e, \ldots)$ and $\left(X^{\prime}, \operatorname{id}_{X^{\prime}}, \ldots\right)$ for some object $X^{\prime}$. Similarly, a right module is a bimodule between $\operatorname{id}_{X^{\prime}}$ and $e$. One can axiomatize (left, say) $e$-modules directly by studying the full subcategory on the objects $\left\{X, X^{\prime}\right\}$ of the category pictured here:
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

One finds that a (left) condensation $e$-module consists of a sequence of condensation cubes $e^{i} m \rightarrow m$.
Example 2.3.6. Suppose that $n=1$, so that a condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots)$ is an object $X \in \mathcal{C}$ together with an idempotent $e^{2}=e$. Then a bimodule between $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}\right)$ and $\left(X_{2}, e_{2}\right)$ is a morphism $X_{1} \stackrel{m}{\leftarrow} X_{2}$ such that $e_{1} m=m=m e_{2}$.
Example 2.3.7. If $(X, Y, f, g, \ldots)$ is a condensation, then $f$ and $g$ are respectively right and left modules for $e=g f$. A simple way to see this (for $g$ ) is to note that in the three-object category pictured in Example 2.3.5, composition with $\mu$ produces an isomorphism $\operatorname{hom}(Y, X) \cong \operatorname{hom}\left(X^{\prime}, X\right)$.

Each condensation monad $e$ is itself an $e$ - $e$-bimodule, simply by letting the requisite $(i, j)$ th cube depend only on $i+j$.

Example 2.3.8. Let $\{\mathrm{pt}\} \in \mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$ denote the $(n-1)$-category with one object and only identity morphisms. Given a condensation monad $(\mathcal{X}, E, \ldots)$ in $\mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$, the $(n-1)$-category of $E$ - $\{\mathrm{pt}\}$ condensation bimodules consists of functors $\mathcal{X} \stackrel{X}{\leftarrow}\{\mathrm{pt}\}$, which is to say objects $X \in \mathcal{X}$, equipped with various maps $E^{k} X \rightarrow E^{l} X$. If $E$ were a unital associative monad rather than a condensation monad, then this category would be precisely the category of what are called in the monad literature " $E$-algebras in $\mathcal{X}$." The functors "forget the condensation $E$-module structure" and "compose with $E$ " witness this category of $E$-algebras as the condensate of $(\mathcal{X}, E, \ldots)$. In particular, $\mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$ contains all condensates.

Our next task is to construct a tensor product of condensation bimodules. We will focus for clarity on the case of tensoring a right $(X, e)$-module $X_{1}^{\prime} \stackrel{m_{1}}{\leftarrow} X$ with a left $e$-module $X \stackrel{m_{2}}{\leftarrow} X_{2}^{\prime}$ to produce a morphism $m_{1} \otimes_{e} m_{2}: X_{2}^{\prime} \rightarrow X_{1}^{\prime}$. The bimodule case is no harder, just more notationally cumbersome.

To motivate the construction, consider the following diagram:
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)

There is clearly a condensation $m_{1} m_{2} \rightarrow \mu_{1} \mu_{2}$, and so there must be a corresponding condensation algebra $\epsilon \in \operatorname{End}\left(m_{1} m_{2}\right)$. Conversely, assuming by induction that Theorem 2.3.2 holds for $(n-1)$ categories, the morphism $\mu_{1} \mu_{2}: X_{2}^{\prime} \rightarrow X_{1}^{\prime}$ is determined by the condensation monad $\left(m_{1} m_{2}, \epsilon, \ldots\right)$.

Proposition 2.3.9. Suppose that $(X, e, \ldots)$ is a condensation monad and that $X_{1}^{\prime} \stackrel{m_{1}}{\leftarrow} X$ and $X \stackrel{m_{2}}{\leftarrow} X_{2}^{\prime}$ are right and left e-modules, respectively. Then $m_{1} m_{2}$ carries a canonical condensation monad $\epsilon$. In the case pictured in ( $\dagger$ ), where $e=g f$ for a condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ and $m_{1}=\mu_{1} f$ and $m_{2}=g \mu_{2}$, the condensation monad $\epsilon \in \operatorname{End}\left(m_{1} m_{2}\right)$ has $\mu_{1} \mu_{2}$ as its condensate.

Definition 2.3.10. Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is an n-category all of whose hom $(n-1)$-categories have all condensates, and assume by induction that Theorem 2.3.2 holds for $(n-1)$-categories. With notation as in Proposition 2.3.9, the tensor product $m_{1} \otimes_{e} m_{2}: X_{2}^{\prime} \rightarrow X_{1}^{\prime}$ is the condensate corresponding to the condensation monad $\left(m_{1} m_{2}, \epsilon, \ldots\right)$.

In particular, in the case pictured in ( $\dagger$ ), we have $m_{1} \otimes_{e} m_{2}=\mu_{1} \mu_{2}$.
Proof of Proposition 2.3.9. The actions of $e$ on the $m_{i}$ s give condensations $m_{1} e \rightarrow m_{1}$ and $e m_{2} \rightarrow$ $m_{2}$. Thinking of $e$ as an $e$-module, these condensations are examples of tensor products, providing canonical isomorphisms $m_{1} \otimes_{e} e \cong m_{1}$ and $e \otimes_{e} m_{2} \cong m_{2}$.

By whiskering, we find two different condensations $m_{1} e m_{2} \rightarrow m_{1} m_{2}$ - in terms of tensor products, the two condensations correspond to the isomorphisms $m_{1} \otimes_{e} e m_{2} \cong m_{1} m_{2}$ and $m_{1} e \otimes_{e} m_{2} \cong$ $m_{1} m_{2}$.

Let $\epsilon_{1}, \epsilon_{2} \in \operatorname{End}\left(m_{1} e m_{2}\right)$ denote the corresponding condensation monads. The fact that $e$ is bimodule implies that these two condensation monads commute. Their product $\varepsilon \in \operatorname{End}\left(m_{1} e m_{2}\right)$ is a condensation monad; the corresponding condensate, if it exists, should be thought of as " $m_{1} \otimes_{e}$ $e \otimes_{e} m_{2}$." Commutativity further implies that we may restrict $\varepsilon$ along either condensation $m_{1} e m_{2} \rightarrow$ $m_{1} m_{2}$ to produce a condensation monad $\epsilon$ on $m_{1} m_{2}$ with condensate, if it exists, $m_{1} \otimes_{e} m_{2}$. But in fact the two restrictions agree, because the isomorphisms $m_{1} \otimes_{e} e \cong m_{1}$ and $e \otimes_{e} m_{2} \cong m_{2}$ are $e$-module isomorphisms. This $\epsilon$ is our desired condensation monad on $m_{1} m_{2}$.

We may now complete the proof of Theorem 2.3.2:

Proof of Theorem 2.3.2. By induction, we may assume the statement of the Theorem for $(n-1)$ categories. Fix a condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots) \in \mathcal{C}$. Suppose that it condenses to two different condensations $\left(X, Y_{1}, f_{1}, g_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X, Y_{2}, f_{2}, g_{2}, \ldots\right)$. Then the $f_{i}$ and $g_{i}$ are $e$-modules by Example 2.3.7, and so there are morphisms $f_{1} \otimes_{e} g_{2}: Y_{2} \rightarrow Y_{1}$ and $f_{2} \otimes_{e} g_{1}: Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{2}$. Their compositions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f_{1} \otimes_{e} g_{2} f_{2} \otimes_{e} g_{1}=f_{1} \otimes_{e} e \otimes_{e} g_{1} \cong f_{1} \otimes_{e} g_{1} \cong \operatorname{id}_{Y_{1}} \\
& f_{2} \otimes_{e} g_{1} f_{1} \otimes_{e} g_{2}=f_{2} \otimes_{e} e \otimes_{e} g_{2} \cong f_{2} \otimes_{e} g_{2} \cong \operatorname{id}_{Y_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with the last isomorphism being the special case $\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}=\mathrm{id}$ of $(\dagger)$. Thus the condensations $\left(X, Y_{1}, f_{1}, g_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X, Y_{2}, f_{2}, g_{2}, \ldots\right)$ are isomorphic.

It remains to show the contractibility of the category of those endomorphisms $(X, Y, f, g, \ldots) \supset$ that restrict to the trivial endomorphism $(X, e, \ldots) \supset$. But in fact this follows from what we have already proved. Indeed, an endomorphism of a condensation $\boldsymbol{\rightarrow} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is simply a diagram in $\mathcal{C}$ of shape $\boldsymbol{\rightarrow} \times\{\bullet \supset\}$, which is the same as a condensation in the category of functors $\{\bullet \supset\} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$. Suppose we have a condensation $(X, Y, f, g, \ldots)$ with an endomorphism which restricts trivially to $(X, e, \ldots)$. Then the corresponding condensation monad in $\operatorname{Fun}(\{\bullet \supset\}, \mathcal{C})$ is the identity morphism on the condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots)$, and so condenses to the identity on $Y$. But it also condenses to the a priori nontrivial morphism of condensations, and we have already established that each condensation monad has at most one condensate.

That there are no higher morphisms of condensations can be handled similarly, by replacing the test category $\{\bullet \supset\}$ with suitable higher categories.

The constructions above also establish:
Theorem 2.3.11. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an n-category all of whose hom $(n-1)$-categories have all condensates.

- There is an $n$-category $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$, called the Karoubi envelope of $\mathcal{C}$, whose objects are the condensation monads in $\mathcal{C}$, whose 1-morphisms are the condensation bimodules, and composition of 1-morphisms is given by tensor product of condensation bimodules. The higher morphisms are the homomorphisms of condensation bimodules.
- $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ has all condensates.
- The functor $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ sending $X \mapsto\left(X, \operatorname{id}_{X}, \ldots\right)$ is fully faithful, and an equivalence if $\mathcal{C}$ has all condensates.
- The construction $\mathcal{C} \mapsto \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is functorial in $\mathcal{C}$ and takes products of $n$-categories to products.
- The inclusion $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is universal in the following sense: if $\mathcal{D}$ is any $n$-category with all condensates, then any functor $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ extends uniquely (up to a contractible space of choices) to a functor $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$.

Proof. It follows from Proposition 2.3.9 that compositions in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ are defined up to a contractible $(n-1)$-category worth of choices (which is the requirement for a weak $n$-category). Associativity (and higher coherences thereof) uses exactly the same argument: a sequence of bimodules $\left(X_{0}, e_{0}\right) \stackrel{m_{1}}{\leftarrow}\left(X_{1}, e_{1}\right) \stackrel{m_{2}}{\leftarrow} \ldots \stackrel{m_{k}}{\leftarrow}\left(X_{k}, e_{k}\right)$ determines $(k-1)$-many condensation monads on $m_{1} m_{2} \cdots m_{k}$; that they commute is precisely the bimodule property of the $m_{i} \mathrm{~s}$; their unique-up-to-a-contractible-space composition is the unique-up-to-a-contractible-space condensate of the product of these commuting condensation monads. The unit bimodule on $(X, e, \ldots)$ is $e$ itself as in Example 2.3.7. The inclusion $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ sending $X \mapsto\left(X, \operatorname{id}_{X}, \ldots\right)$ is a functor and fully faithful simply from unpacking the definition of bimodule between $\left(X, \mathrm{id}_{X}, \ldots\right)$ and $\left(X^{\prime}, \mathrm{id}_{X^{\prime}}, \ldots\right)$ : such a bimodule is nothing but a morphism $X \leftarrow X^{\prime}$.

Suppose $((X, e, \ldots),(E, \ldots), \ldots)$ is a condensation monad in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$, which is to say that $(E, \ldots)$ is a bimodule between $(X, e, \ldots)$ and itself, equipped with the data making it into a condensation

monad. Then $E: X \rightarrow X$ is a condensation monad on $X$, and the extra data is precisely the necessary data needed to make $e$ and $E$ commute. The condensate in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ of $((X, e, \ldots),(E, \ldots), \ldots)$ is the product condensation monad $(X, e E, \ldots)$ in $\mathcal{C}$. If $\mathcal{C}$ already had all condensates, then the assignment sending each condensation monad to its condensate, which is well-defined (up to contractible choices) by Theorem 2.3.2, provides the inverse to the inclusion $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$.

The second-to-last claim in the Theorem follows from the facts that: $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is built entirely out of diagrams in $\mathcal{C}$ (as opposed to, say, colimits in $\mathcal{C}$ ); diagrams are preserved by arbitrary functors; for any diagram shape $\diamond$, a $\diamond$-shaped diagram in $\mathcal{C}_{1} \times \mathcal{C}_{2}$ is the same as a $\diamond$-shaped diagram in $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ together with a $\diamond$-shaped diagram in $\mathcal{C}_{2}$.

Given a functor $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$, functoriality of $\operatorname{Kar}(-)$ extends it to $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{D})$. But if $\mathcal{D}$ has all condensates, then $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{D}) \cong \mathcal{D}$. This gives the existence part of the last claim in the Theorem. The uniqueness follows from the fact that condensation monads, and condensations, are preserved by all functors, and that condensates are unique when they exist.
Remark 2.3.12. If the hom $(n-1)$-categories in $\mathcal{C}$ did not have all their condensates, then to construct $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ we would first take the Karoubi envelope of all the hom $(n-1)$-categories; without this step, the composition of bimodules might not exist or might not by well-defined up to a contractible space. This local Karoubi completion step is allowed (in the sense that taking the Karoubi envelope of all hom- $(n-1)$-categories in an $n$-category produces a new $n$-category) because of the second-to-last bullet point of Theorem 2.3.11. By induction, for arbitrary $\mathcal{C}$ with no conditions on existence of condensates, $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ will again by built entirely out of diagrams in $\mathcal{C}$, but those diagrams will be more complicated. For example, if the hom $(n-1)$-categories in $\mathcal{C}$ do not have all condensates, then among the objects of $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ are "condensation monads" $(X, e, \ldots)$ in $\mathcal{C}$ where the "morphism" $e$ is not just a 1-morphism in $\mathcal{C}$ but is itself a condensation monad $e=\left(e_{0}, \epsilon, \ldots\right)$ in $\operatorname{End}(X)$.
Example 2.3.13. As explained in $\S 1.3$, the application of Theorem 2.3.11 that we will be most interested in is the following. Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is a monoidal $(n-1)$-category with all condensates. Write $B \mathcal{C}$ for the corresponding one-object monoidal $n$-category. Then $B \mathcal{C}$ satisfies the conditions of Theorem 2.3.11, and so there is a universal $n$-category $\operatorname{Kar}(B \mathcal{C})$ with all condensates and a fully faithful map $B \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(B \mathcal{C})$. The importance of the construction $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{B}(-))$ justifies giving it a simple name. We will call it $\Sigma(-)$.

The reason for the name " $\Sigma(-)$ " is because we think of it as a type of "suspension" operation. The construction B : $\{$ monoidal $(n-1)$-categories $\} \rightarrow\{$ pointed $n$-categories $\}$ is left-adjoint to the loops construction that takes a pointed $n$-category $(\mathcal{C}, 1 \in \mathcal{C})$ to $\Omega \mathcal{C}:=\operatorname{End}_{\mathcal{C}}(1)$. (An $n$-category is pointed when it is equipped with a distinguished object.) The universality in the last part of Theorem 2.3.11 says that $\operatorname{Kar}(-)$ is the left-adjoint of the inclusion $\{n$-categories with all condensates $\} \hookrightarrow\{n$-categories $\}$. Together with the full faithfulness of $B \mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(B \mathcal{C})$, we find that $\Sigma(-)$ is the left-adjoint to $\Omega(-)$ in the world of condensation-complete categories.

Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is not just monoidal but symmetric monoidal. Then $B \mathcal{C}$ is also symmetric monoidal (compare [CS19, §3.3]) and, since $\operatorname{Kar}(-)$ preserves products, so is $\operatorname{Kar}(B \mathcal{C})=\Sigma \mathcal{C}$. This allows us to iterate suspension, defining for example a symmetric monoidal $(d+1)$-category $\Sigma^{d} \mathbf{V e c}_{\mathbb{K}}$ for any field $\mathbb{K}$.
2.4. Boundary conditions and lattice Hamiltonians. When can a gapped topological system $Y$ be reconstructed from a gapped topological system $X$ by "condensing" some degrees of freedom? Let us list some reasonable hypotheses about physical condensation of gapped topological systems. By the end of the list, we will discover the category-theoretical condensations and condensation monads described above.

First, let us require that a physical condensation of $X$ onto $Y$ can be performed in one macroscopic region, independently of other distant macroscopic regions. Specifically, let us pick a coordinate direction $x$, and suppose that it is possible to condense to phase $Y$ in the domain $x \ll 0$ while

remaining in system $X$ for $x \gg 0$. After zooming out to a sufficiently macrosopic length scale, such a partial condensation will produce a codimension-1 interface $f$ from $X$ to $Y$. (In order to match composition order for functions, our convention will be that an interface "from $X$ to $Y$ " is one with $X$ on the right and $Y$ on the left.) If instead we condensed to phase $Y$ in the $x \gg 0$ region while remaining in phase $X$ for $x \ll 0$, then we would produce an interface $g$ from $Y$ to $X$. We require that whatever this "partial condensation" procedure is, the interfaces $f$ and $g$ it produces should be gapped and topological. In particular, they may be translated freely in the $x$-direction without changing their low-energy properties, so long as they remain sufficiently far from any other defect in the system.

Now, for some intermediate length scale $L>0$, consider condensing from $X$ to $Y$ both for $x<0$ and for $x>L$. We should be able to complete the job to obtain a uniform $Y$-phase if we also condense in the intermediate region $0 \leq x \leq L$. The two partial condensations together produce the composition $f g$ of interfaces from $Y$ to $X$ and back to $Y$. Being able to complete the job is simply the ability to condense from the $f g$ interface to the invisible interface $\mathrm{id}_{Y}$. By induction, we learn:

Lemma 2.4.1. Under mild assumptions about the nature of "physical condensation" of gapped topological systems, any physical condensation of phase $X$ onto phase $Y$ produces a condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ in the sense of Definitions 1.2.4 and 2.1.1.

In order to fully identify physical condensation with Definitions 1.2.4 and 2.1.1, we must reverse the construction, explaining how to produce phase $Y$ by condensing some degrees of freedom in phase $X$ if we are given the interfaces $f$ and $g$ and a way of condensing $f g$ onto $\mathrm{id}_{Y}$. We will employ a standard condensed matter procedure: we will enlarge the low-energy system of $X$ by proliferating some collection of defects and then adding some new local Hamiltonian on these extra degrees of freedom which makes the new system $Y$ gapped and topological. Our method will be a physical version of the categorical discussion from $\S 2.3$ of producing the condensate of a given condensation monad.

To this end, consider the opposite composition $e=g f$. It represents a thin slab of the $Y$ phase embedded within the $X$ phase. Having started with a categorical condensation $X \rightarrow Y$, this $e$-interface carries a condensation monad structure. By induction, the condensation $e^{2} \rightarrow e$ is precisely the data needed to fill in the space between two $Y$ slabs to produce a single thicker slab, and associativity produces the information how to partially merge collections of consecutive slabs of $Y$ within a bulk of $X$ phase.

Crucially, merely the condensation monad $e$ contains enough information to give a sort of mesoscopic "topological effective description" of the original microscopic condensation procedure. To obtain $Y$ :
(1) Proliferate the $e$ defects throughout $X$. Imagine these defects as thin slabs of $Y$.
(2) Turn on local Hamiltonians which merge consecutive slabs into a uniform $Y$ phase.

Why can step (2) be performed? For any pair of consecutive slabs, the condensation $e^{2} \rightarrow e$ is a condensation of $(d-1)$-dimensional systems, and so by induction has a local Hamiltonian description. But the higher commuting condensation cubes in Definition 2.2.1 means that these local Hamiltonians commute!
Remark 2.4.2. More precisely, the higher-dimensional commuting condensation cubes provide us with compatible collections of invertible maps which can be used to deform the neighbouring networks of defects away from the location where any given local projector will act. The actual projectors are defined by conjugating the original local projectors by the maps which move away other spectating defects.

The induction starts with $(0+1)$-dimensional, aka anyon, condensation, where it produces a projector, aka idempotent, Hamiltonian (compare $\S 1.2$ and Example 2.4.5). After unpacking the

recursion, we find a network of interfaces and defects in an ambient $X$ phase equipped with a (complicated, but algorithmic) commuting projector Hamiltonian. This network gives a mesoscopic "topological effective description" of the phase $Y$.

The uniqueness proved in Theorem 2.3.2 is exactly what is needed to show that, if we did start with some generic "physical condensation" of $X$ onto $Y$ and then ran the above procedure to first extract a categorical condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ and then to build a mesoscopic lattice, then we would produce a system in the phase $Y$ (and not some other phase). Specifically, Theorem 2.3.2 produces a canonical invertible defect between the original system $Y$ and the mesoscopic lattice phase.
Remark 2.4.3. Condensation bimodules can be interpreted similarly. Suppose that we have two systems $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$ which can be condensed to $Y_{1}$ and $Y_{2}$ respectively, and we want to describe some interface $\mu$ interpolating from $Y_{1}$ to $Y_{2}$. We get for free an interface $m=g_{2} \mu f_{1}$ from $X_{1}$ to $X_{2}$, together with condensations which allow one to merge the $m$ interface with slabs $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ of $Y_{1}$ or $Y_{2}$. This data will allow us to reconstruct $\mu$ by a mesoscopic condensation procedure, where we proliferate $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ interfaces on the two sides of $m$ and then turning on local (commuting projector) Hamiltonians which merge the consecutive $Y_{1}$ and $Y_{2}$ slabs to each other and to $m$. As long as we are given an $m$ with the correct properties, the procedure will always go through and give some gapped topological defect $\mu$.

In the special case when $X$ is in the trivial phase, so that $f$ and $g$ are boundaries for $Y$ and $e$ is actually a phase in one dimension lower, we find a construction of $Y$ from a network of $e$-systems, analogous to the string-net construction of a quantum double model in $(2+1)$ dimensions [LW05]. Recall from $\S 1.3$ and Example 2.3.13 the notation $\Sigma \mathcal{C}=\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{BC})$, where $\mathcal{C}$ is a symmetric monoidal $n$-category with all condensates, and $\mathrm{BC}$ is the one-object $(n+1)$-category with endomorphism category $\mathcal{C}$. Note that $\mathrm{BC}$ is symmetric monoidal if $\mathcal{C}$ is - see [CS19, §3.3] - and hence so too is $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$ by employing the last sentence of Theorem 2.3.11. By induction, we find:
Theorem 2.4.4. Let $\mathcal{V}$ denote the symmetric monoidal 1-category of gapped topological $(0+1)$ dimensional systems. For example, for bosonic systems without any symmetry or time reversal enhancement, $\mathcal{V}$ is equivalent to the category $\mathbf{V e c}_{\mathcal{C}}$ of finite-dimensional vector spaces over $\mathbb{C}$, for fermionic systems $\mathcal{V}$ is equivalent to the category $\mathbf{S V e c}_{\mathcal{C}}$ of finite-dimensional supervector spaces, and for $G$-enriched bosonic phases $\mathcal{V}$ is equivalent to the category $\operatorname{Rep}(G)$ of finite-dimensional $G$-representations.

Then $\Sigma^{d} \mathcal{V}$ is equivalent to the category of $(d+1)$-dimensional gapped topological phases which can be condensed, via gapped topological interfaces, from the vacuum. Furthermore, every object in $\Sigma^{d} \mathcal{V}$ (and every morphism, by Remark 2.4.3) determines a commuting projector Hamiltonian system. That commuting projector Hamiltonian system provides a mesoscopic "topological effective description" of the corresponding $(d+1)$-dimensional phase.

By " $(d+1)$-dimensional" we mean, of course, a system in $d$ spatial dimensions plus 1 time dimension. Corollary 4.1.3 gives a TQFT analogue.
Example 2.4.5. Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are $(0+1)$-dimensional objects, aka anyons, possibly embedded into a larger ambient gapped phase $\Phi$. The "interfaces" $f$ and $g$ are local operations which can interpolate between the two anyons. The condition $f g=\mathrm{id}_{Y}$ tells us that the composition of the two local operations acts trivially on the anyon $Y$, i.e. $f$ and $g$ tell us how to embed the anyon $Y$ as a direct summand within $X$.

If we are given any Hamiltonian realization of $\Phi$ with a local defect trapping the $X$ anyon at some location, then we can simply add a small negative multiple of the projector $e=g f$ to the Hamiltonian in order to get a new Hamiltonian whose ground states only include the anyon $Y$ at that location. This is the condensation procedure in $(0+1)$ dimensions.
Example 2.4.6. In $(1+1)$ dimensions, $X$ and $Y$ will be one-dimensional string defects, possibly embedded into a larger ambient gapped phase $\Phi$. The $f$ and $g$ interfaces will be anyons interpolating

between $X$ and $Y$ and we require the fusion $f g$ to contain the trivial anyon $\operatorname{id}_{Y}$ as a direct summand. On the other hand, $e$ will be some anyon in $X$, such that we can find $e$ as a direct summand in $e^{2}$, with appropriate associativity constraints identifying a canonical choice of the $e$ summand inside $e^{3}$ (or any higher power of $e$ ). In fact, as explained more fully in Example 3.0.1, $e$ will be a (nonunital) special Frobenius algebra object in the category of anyons in $X$.

If we have some Hamiltonian realization of $\Phi, X$, and $e$, then we can introduce a mesoscopic lattice of $e$ defects. We can produce a new Hamiltonian by adding to the old one some small negative multiple of the projectors $e^{2} \rightarrow e$ for all consecutive pairs of $e$ anyons. This gives an effective Hamiltonian description of the $Y$ system as the condensate of $e$-anyons in $X$.

This $(1+1)$-dimensional anyon condensation procedure is well known. See e.g. [KS10, CR12]
Example 2.4.7. In $(2+1)$ dimensions, $f$ and $g$ will be string defects, with $f g$ being a string which can condense to the trivial interface $\mathrm{id}_{Y}$ by condensing some anyon supported on the string $f g$. The interface $e$ will be some interface in $X$ with the property that the composition $e^{2}$ can be condensed to $e$ by condensing some anyon supported on $e^{2}$. This anyon can be thought of as a defect at which $e^{2}$ is fused to $e$ and then back to $e^{2}$. Again, there will be various associativity constraints which guarantee that consecutive pairs of interfaces in a long composition $e^{n}$ can be condensed independently of each other. These constraints give invertible operators which interpolate between configurations decorated by networks of $e$ defects of various topology and projectors which can be used to eliminate "bubbles" from the network.

The construction of an Hamiltonian for $Y$ proceeds as above, starting from a Hamiltonian for $X$ decorated by some regular network of $e$ defects and adding small negative multiples of the projectors which eliminate individual faces of the network. A version of this construction has been studied in [CRS17a, CRS18].

# 3. Unitality 

This section is motivated by a mismatch between between our condensation algebras and bimodules, and the algebras and bimodules usually used in topological field theory. Our goal is to show that under mild hypotheses, the two versions give equivalent results. The mismatch is visible already in two (spacetime) dimensions. (Although our motivation is in category number $n=2$, we will of course phrase as many results as possible for arbitrary $n$.) Two-dimensional TQFTs are usually described in terms of (finite-dimensional) unital associative algebras which enjoy the property of being separable [SP11]. As explained in $\S 2.2$, the condensation algebras that make up our 2-category $\Sigma \mathbf{V e c}=\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{BVec})$ are, instead, a type of nonunital noncounital bialgebra. In detail, we have:

Example 3.0.1. Let $(\mathcal{C}, \otimes)$ be a monoidal 1-category. A condensation algebra in $\mathcal{C}$, i.e. a condensation monad in the one-object 2 -category $\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C}$, consists of the following data:

- An object $e \in \mathcal{C}$.
- A "multiplication" map mult : $e \otimes e \rightarrow e$.
- A "comultiplication" map comult : $e \rightarrow e \otimes e$.

These data are subject to the following axioms:
(1) The multiplication and comultiplication are together a split surjection $e^{\otimes 2} \rightarrow e$.
(2) The multiplication map $e \otimes e \rightarrow e$ is associative.
(3) The comultiplication map $e \rightarrow e \otimes e$ is coassociative.
(4) The idempotent comult o mult : $e^{\otimes 2} \rightarrow e \rightarrow e^{\otimes 2}$ is equal to both $(e \otimes$ mult $) \circ($ comult $\otimes e)$ : $e^{\otimes 2} \rightarrow e^{\otimes 3} \rightarrow e^{\otimes 2}$ and $($ mult $\otimes e) \circ\left(e \otimes\right.$ comult $): e^{\otimes 2} \rightarrow e^{\otimes 3} \rightarrow e^{\otimes 2}$.
These axioms are precisely the axioms for $e$ to be a nonunital special Frobenius algebra. Axioms (2), (3), and (4) define "nonunital Frobenius algebra" (axiom (4) is called the Frobenius axiom), and axiom (1) is the definition of "special." There is a familiar string diagrammatics for bicategories

and monoidal categories. Our convention will be to read composition from left to right and from bottom to top. Writing $e=\frac{1}{f}$ and the multiplication and comultiplication as $\frac{1}{m}$ and $\frac{1}{n}$, the axioms read:
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)

Remark 3.0.2. Axioms (2) and (3) follow from axioms (1) and (4). Checking this is a fun exercise left to the reader. Hint: Create a bubble using (1), move it around using (4), and then collapse it using (1).

A left $e$-module $m$, which we will denote in our string diagrams simply as a solid edge $\mid$, comes with a left $e$-action $x \mid: e \otimes m \rightarrow m$ and a left $e$-coaction $x \mid: m \rightarrow e \otimes m$, satifying versions of specialness, (co)associativity, and the Frobenius relation:
![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)

Remark 3.0.3. In a monoidal $n$-category with $n>1$, a condensation algebra is again a special Frobenius algebra, defined so as to accommodate the higher categoricity: first, (co)associativity and the Frobenius axioms are imposed only up to coherent homotopy (all the coherence data takes the shape of various associahedra); second, the specialness axiom is modified to the presence of a condensation mult o comult $\rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{e}$. The data of this condensation provide the ingredients needed to draw bubbles of dimension $\leq n$, and say that an $n$-dimensional bubble can be created or removed. The (co)associativity and Frobenius axioms allow such a bubble to be moved around freely.
3.1. Unital condensations. Consider a condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ in an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ with $n \geq 2$. The data of this condensation includes:

- the objects $X$ and $Y$;
- morphisms $f: X \rightarrow Y$ and $g: Y \rightarrow X$;
- 2-morphisms $\phi: f g \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ and $\gamma: \mathrm{id}_{Y} \Rightarrow f g$;
- 3- through $n$-morphisms. When $n=2$, these consist just of the equality $\phi \gamma=\operatorname{id}_{\mathrm{id}_{Y}}$.

Definition 3.1.1. With notation as above, the condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ is unital if $\phi: f g \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ is the counit of an adjunction $f \dashv g$, i.e. if there exists a unit $\eta: \mathrm{id}_{X} \Rightarrow e=g f$ such that the "zig-zag" compositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f \stackrel{f \eta}{\Longrightarrow} f g f \stackrel{\phi f}{\Longrightarrow} f \\
& g \stackrel{\eta g}{\Longrightarrow} g f g \stackrel{g \phi}{\Longrightarrow} g
\end{aligned}
$$

are (equivalent to) identities.
The condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ is counital if $\gamma: \operatorname{id}_{Y} \Rightarrow f g$ is the unit of an adjunction $g \dashv f$, i.e. if there exists a counit $\epsilon: e=g f \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{X}$ such that the "zig-zag" compositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f \stackrel{\gamma f}{\Longrightarrow} f g f \stackrel{f \epsilon}{\Longrightarrow} f \\
& g \stackrel{g \gamma}{\Longrightarrow} g f g \stackrel{\epsilon f}{\Longrightarrow} g
\end{aligned}
$$

are (equivalent to) identities.

We will repeat and elaborate on this (well-known) definition of adjunction $f \dashv g$ between 1morphisms in a higher category in $\S 4.1$. In the special case of 2-categories, the paper [DR18] proposes categorifying the 1-categorical notion of "split surjection" not to our notion of "condensation" but rather to the following notion of "separable adjunction":

Definition 3.1.2. A separable adjunction in a 2-category consists of objects $X$ and $Y, 1$-morphisms $f: X \rightarrow Y$ and $g: Y \rightarrow X$, and 2-morphisms $\phi: f g \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ and $\eta: \mathrm{id}_{X} \Rightarrow g f$ satisfying the first set of conditions from Definition 3.1.1, such that there exists a 2-morphism $\gamma: \operatorname{id}_{Y} \Rightarrow f g$ with $\phi \gamma=\operatorname{id}_{\mathrm{id}_{Y}}$. More generally, an adjunction $f \dashv g$ in an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is separable if the counit of the adjunction $\phi: f g \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ is part of a condensation $f g \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ in $\operatorname{End}_{\mathcal{C}}(Y)$.

Remark 3.1.3. The data of $\gamma$ is not part of the data of a separable adjunction - only its existence is required. A choice of $\gamma$ might be called a separation of the adjunction $f \dashv g$, in which case what we have called a "unital condensation" could equivalently be called a separated, as opposed to separable, adjunction.

Separable adjunctions are fairly common in nature. However, if a 1-category $\mathcal{C}$ is treated as a 2category with only identity 2-morphisms, then separable adjunctions in $\mathcal{C}$ end up not corresponding to split surjections, but rather to isomorphisms. This is why we prefer condensations over separable adjunctions as a categorification of "split surjection." Nevertheless, we will show that the two notions often lead to equivalent "Karoubi envelopes."

Proposition 3.1.4. Suppose that $(X, Y, f, g, \phi, \gamma, \ldots)$ is a condensation and that $f$ admits a right adjoint $f^{R}$. Then there is a unital condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ whose 1-morphisms are $f$ and $f^{R}$. If $g$ admits a left adjoint $g^{L}$, then there is a unital condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ with 1-morphisms $g^{L}$ and $g$. Similarly, if $f$ admits a left adjoint $f^{L}$, then $f$ and $f^{L}$ participate in a counital condensation $X \rightarrow Y$, and if $g$ admits a right adjoint $g^{R}$, then $g$ and $g^{R}$ participate in a counital condensation $X \rightarrow Y$.

Proof. We will prove the first statement; the others follow by reversing the order of composition of 1- or 2-morphisms. Our goal is to construct a condensation $f f^{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$.

Let $\eta: \mathrm{id}_{X} \Rightarrow f^{R} f$ and $\epsilon: f f^{R} \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ denote the unit and counit of the adjunction $f \dashv f^{R}$. Let $\tilde{\gamma}$ denote the composition

$$
\mathrm{id}_{Y} \stackrel{\tilde{\gamma}}{\Longrightarrow} f g \stackrel{f g g}{\Longrightarrow} f f^{R} f g \stackrel{f f^{R} \phi}{\Longrightarrow} f f^{R}
$$

We claim that $\eta$ and $\tilde{\gamma}$ participate in a condensation $f f^{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$. Indeed, the following "string diagram" computation (with 1-morphisms drawn from right to left, and 2-morphisms from bottom to top) makes clear that the compositions $\epsilon \circ \tilde{\gamma}$ and $\phi \circ \gamma$ agree, and so to complete the condensation $f f^{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ we may use the condensation $\epsilon \circ \tilde{\gamma}=\phi \circ \gamma \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{id}_{Y}}$.
![img-13.jpeg](img-13.jpeg)

The white exterior region in each diagram is the object $X$, and the shaded interior region is the object $Y$. The boxed subdiagram on the left is the string diagram for $\tilde{\gamma}$. The second equality is simply the fact that $\eta$ and $\epsilon$ are the unit and counit of an adjunction between $f$ and $f^{R}$.

Remark 3.1.5. In the proof of Proposition 3.1.4, and especially in the proof of Theorem 3.1.7 below, we have doubled down on our convention to write " $=$ " to mean "isomorphic, canonically up to a contractible space of choices." This is consistent with the "principle of univalence" that should be built into any model-independent theory of higher categories. Readers uncomfortable with this principle can decide that $\mathcal{C}$ is merely a 2 -category: the results remain nontrivial, and compare our theory of 2-dimensional Karoubi completion to the version from [DR18].

Given either a separable adjunction or a unital condensation (aka separated adjunction), one may consider the endomorphism $e=g f: X \rightarrow X$. We observed already that the morphism $\phi: f g \rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ makes $e$ into an associative algebra object in $\operatorname{End}(X)$; the unit $\eta$ is precisely what is needed to make $e$ into a unital algebra. It is a general fact, true at arbitrary category number, that if an associative algebra admits a unit, then the unit is unique (up to a contractible space of choices): unitality is a property. We are therefore justified to define a unital condensation monad to be a condensation monad whose associative multiplication is unital. Dually, a counital condensation monad is one whose coassociative comultiplication is counital. A separable monad is a unital associative monad which can be extended to a unital condensation monad.

Remark 3.1.6. Suppose that $e$ is a unital condensation monad and that $m$ is a (left, say) condensation $e$-module. The definition of condensation module does not mention the unit in $e$, and in the associative case it is easy to construct examples of a unital associative algebra with a module-as-a-nonunital-associative-algebra for which the unit does not act as the identity. Nevertheless, in the condensation case the unit in $e$ automatically acts as the identity on $m$. Indeed, the unit in $e$ acts as the identity on the composition $e \otimes_{e} m$, because it acts on the composition through its action on $e$, but this composition is isomorphic to $m$.

Theorem 3.1.7. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an n-category all of whose hom $(n-1)$-categories have all condensates. Suppose that $(X, e, \ldots)$ is a condensation monad in $\mathcal{C}$ whose underlying 1-morphism $e: X \rightarrow X$ has a right adjoint $e^{R}$. Then $(X, e, \ldots)$ is equivalent as an object of $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ to an object represented by a unital condensation monad, and also to an object represented by a counital condensation monad.

Since objects and morphisms in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ are types of algebras and bimodules, equivalence in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is a type of Morita equivalence.

Proof. Through only the most mild abuse of notation, let us write $X \in \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ for the object represented by the condensation monad $(X, \mathrm{id}, \ldots)$, and $e \in \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ for the object represented by $(X, e, \ldots)$. Theorem 2.3.11 provides a condensation $X \nrightarrow e$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. The 1-morphisms $f: X \rightarrow e$ and $g: e \rightarrow X$ are, respectively, $e$ thought of as a left condensation $e$-module and $e$ thought of as a right condensation $e$-module.

We will show that the 1-morphism $f: X \rightarrow e$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ admits a right adjoint $f^{R}$. A similar construction produces a right adjoint to $g$. Before giving the construction, we explain why these right adjoints suffice to prove the Theorem. Indeed, by Proposition 3.1.4, the right adjoint $f^{R}$ provides a unital condensation $X \nrightarrow e$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$, which is to say a unital condensation monad $e^{\prime}=f^{R} \otimes_{e} f: X \rightarrow X$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. The inclusion $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is fully faithful, and so $e^{\prime}$ determines a unital condensation monad in the original category $\mathcal{C}$. But $e^{\prime}$ is constructed from a condensation $X \rightarrow e$, and so it condenses (in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ ) to $e$, and on the other hand it automatically condenses to $e^{\prime}$. Theorem 2.3.2 finishes the job: $e$ is equivalent in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ to the unital condensation monad $e^{\prime}$. By using $g^{R}$ instead, we would have constructed a counital $e^{\prime}$.

It remains to construct $f^{R}$. It is supposed to be a morphism $e \rightarrow X$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$, which is to say it is supposed to be a right condensation $e$-module. Since $f$ is " $e$ as an $e$-module," and since $e$ admits a right-adjoint $e^{R}$, it is tempting to think that $f^{R}$ will be " $e^{R}$ as an $e$-module." In fact, $e^{R}$ is naturally a right comodule for the (noncounital) coalgebra structure on $e$, with coaction related by the adjunction to the action of $e$ on itself, but it is not naturally a right module for the algebra

structure, and hence not naturally a condensation module. (On the left, it is naturally a module but not a comodule.)

That said, the natural comodule structure on $e^{R}$ is enough to define a version of the tensor product " $e^{R} \otimes_{e} e$." This tensor product will be our condensation module $f^{R}$. Specifically, $e^{R} e$ supports a condensation monad whose underlying 2-morphism $e^{R} e \Rightarrow e^{R} e$ is given by the following string diagram. (As above, our conventions for string diagrams is that composition of 1-morphisms is from right to left, and composition of 2-morphisms is from bottom to top.)
![img-14.jpeg](img-14.jpeg)

The upward-pointing edges denote $e$, and the downward-pointing edges are $e^{R}$. The cup is the unit of the adjunction between $e$ and $e^{R}$. The trivalent vertices are the multiplication and comultiplication on $e$, rotated using the adjunction $e \dashv e^{R}$. The tensor product $f^{R}=$ " $e^{R} \otimes_{e} e$ " is the condensate produced from this condensation monad. We emphasize that $f^{R}$ and $e^{R}$ are typically not the same as 1-morphisms: the isomorphism $m \otimes_{e} e \cong m$ holds when $m$ is a condensation $e$-module, or when $e$ is a unital algebra (with unital action on $m$ ), but not for arbitrary modules of a nonunital algebra.

It is clear that $f^{R}$ is a right condensation $e$-module: the right condensation action of $e$ on itself commutes with the left action used to define $f^{R}$. We will henceforth use white regions to denote the object $X \in \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$, and shading to denote $e$, so that an edge with shading on the side means a (bi)module. So for example the composition $f^{R} \otimes_{e} f$ will be denoted:
![img-15.jpeg](img-15.jpeg)

Recall from Definition 2.3.10 that $\otimes_{e}$ is implementing by condensing a network of $e$-edges, so that for instance $\stackrel{\text { int }}{+}=\stackrel{+}{\vdash}=\stackrel{-}{\vdash}$. In particular, $f^{R} \otimes_{e} f$ is simply the underlying 1-morphism $X \rightarrow X$ of $f^{R}$, without its structure as a right condensation $e$-module.

To complete the proof, we must witness the adjunction $f \dashv f^{R}$, i.e. we must give unit and counit maps $\operatorname{id}_{X} \Rightarrow f^{R} \otimes_{e} f$ and $f \otimes_{X} f^{R} \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{e}$. The unit $\operatorname{id}_{X} \Rightarrow f^{R} \otimes_{e} f$ of the adjunction is given by splitting a "bubble collapsing" condensation monad supported by the following diagram:
![img-16.jpeg](img-16.jpeg)

The counit $f \otimes_{X} f^{R} \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{e}$ is the splitting of a "bubble collapsing" condensation monad supported by:
![img-17.jpeg](img-17.jpeg)

Note that is a picture of the " $e$ as an $e$-bimodule," which is to say the identity 1-morphism id ${ }_{e}$ in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$.

A diagrammatic calculation (left to the reader) confirms that these are in fact the unit and counit of an adjunction $f \dashv f^{R}$.
![img-18.jpeg](img-18.jpeg)

In both cases the calculation uses the adjunction $e \dashv e^{R}$, the Frobenius axtioms for $e$, and the "bubble collapsing" condensation monads (not drawn).
3.2. Physical interpretation: the state-operator map. Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are two gapped topological $(1+1)$-dimensional phases and that we have a way of (physically) condensing from $X$ to $Y$. In $\S 2.4$ we constructed a (categorical) condensation $X \rightarrow Y$ by partially condensing in the $x>0$ or $x<0$ domains. The interfaces $f$ and $g$ produced by this procedure cannot be literally "the same" because they point in different directions. In a TQFT context, it would be natural to request

that they are related by $180^{\circ}$ rotation. This request is much less natural in the condensed matter context, where any notion of "rotation of an interface" is at best emergent in the low-energy. We have mentioned already that the "topological" limits of gapped topological condensed matter phases are, a priori, actually framed-topological. It is certainly feasible that there may be condensation procedures that couple nontrivially to the microscopic lattice framing. In this case it can happen that counterclockwise $180^{\circ}$-rotation by is not equivalent to clockwise $180^{\circ}$-rotation, even if both rotations make sense. The former produces the left adjoint $f^{L}$ of an interface $f$, whereas the latter produces the right adjoint $f^{R}$. That we may have $f^{L} \neq f^{R}$ illustrates the a priori unnaturalness of demanding that $g$ equal either of them. Nevertheless, Proposition 3.1.4 shows that, assuming these interfaces can be rotated, then we lose no generality by requesting that $g=f^{R}$, or that $g=f^{L}$, if we so desire.

Similarly, unitality for a condensation monad is natural in the (oriented) TQFT context, where the space of states on a segment (provided that "the same" boundary condition is used at both ends of the segment) is naturally equipped not just with a multiplication map (given by adiabatically merging two segments to one) and a comultiplication map (adiabatically cutting a segment in two) satisfying the Frobenius axioms, but also with a unit and counit corresponding to half-disk geometries. Of course, these half disks only exist if we use "the same" boundary condition for the two ends of the segment (i.e. if $g=f^{L}=f^{R}$ ).

Suppose we are given a nonunital condensation algebra $e$, and we construct, following Theorem 3.1.7, a Morita-equivalent unital condensation algebra $e^{\prime}=e^{R} \otimes_{e} e$. By opening up the top of $(\ddagger)$, we can recognize $e^{\prime}$ as the space of insertions at " $*$ " in the following diagram:
![img-19.jpeg](img-19.jpeg)

As above, the shaded region denotes the phase produced by condensing the $e$-anyon. For comparison, the original nonunital monad $e$ is the space of states for the condensed system.

But this $e^{\prime}$ is precisely the space of boundary operators for the boundary condition 2. The multiplication on $e^{\prime}$ is precisely the multiplication of boundary operators. Furthermore, there is a state-operator map $e \rightarrow e^{\prime}$ described by the string diagram
![img-20.jpeg](img-20.jpeg)
which is an isomorphism if and only if $e$ was already unital - only in the unital case do we get a true "state-operator correspondence."

Remark 3.2.1. Any nonunital associative algebra $A$, not necessarily a condensation algebra, determines a unital associative algebra, called the multiplier algebra of $A$, defined as the algebra $\operatorname{End}_{A}(A)$ of endomorphisms of $A$ thought of as a left $A$-module. The multiplication map determines an associative algebra morphism $A \rightarrow \operatorname{End}_{A}(A)$. The construction $e \rightsquigarrow e^{\prime}$ from Theorem 3.1.7 is precisely this construction $A \rightsquigarrow \operatorname{End}_{A}(A)$ in the special case where $e$ is a (right-adjunctible) condensation algebra.

The Morita equivalence $e \simeq e^{\prime}$ from Theorem 3.1.7 is special to the condensation case: for general associative algebras there is no sense in which $A$ and $\operatorname{End}_{A}(A)$ are Morita equivalent.
3.3. Condensation bimodules vs unital algebra bimodules. Theorem 3.1.7 allows us in many cases to replace condensation algebras with unital condensation algebras. In order to get a comparison with unital separable algebras, we must show that the choice of comultiplication can be dropped.
Lemma 3.3.1. Let $e$ be a condensation monad in an $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$. Suppose that $m$ is left $e$-module with respect to the (nonunital) associative algebra structure on $e$. If the $e$-module structure on $m$ extends to a condensation e-module structure, then it does so in a unique way (up to a contractible space of choices).
Proof. By mimicking the proof of Theorem 3.1.7, we can construct a "tensor product" $\tilde{m}=$ " $e \otimes_{e} m$ " which will be automatically a left condensation $e$-module. Indeed, consider the (2-)morphism $e \circ m \Rightarrow e \circ m$ defined by the following string diagram:
![img-21.jpeg](img-21.jpeg)

Here and throughout, $\dot{+}$ denotes the condensation monad $e$ and $\}$ denotes $m$, and the trivalent vertices denote various (co)multiplications and actions. Just using coassociativity of $\stackrel{\text { N }}{\leftrightarrows}$, associativity of the action $\mathcal{A}$, and the specialness axiom for $e$ (see Remark 3.0.3 for the $n>2$ case), one can produce on this (2-)morphism a condensation monad structure. Condensing this monad defines $\tilde{m}=e \otimes_{e} m$.

When the $e$-action on $m$ extends to a condensation action already, then $\tilde{m}$ will be isomorphic, as a condensation module, to $m$. Thus all extensions, if they exist, are canonically equivalent.
Lemma 3.3.2. Let $e$ be a (nonunital) associative monad in $\mathcal{C}$. If the associative monad structure on e extends to a condensation monad structure, then all extensions are canonically "condensation Morita equivalent," i.e. canonically equivalent as objects of $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$.
Proof. Suppose that $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ are two condensation monads whose underlying associative monads are both $e$. Consider $e$ as an associative $e$-e-bimodule. Then, as in the proof of Lemma 3.3.1, construct the tensor product $e_{1} \otimes_{e_{1}} e \otimes_{e_{2}} e_{2}$. It is by construction a condensation $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodule. But its underlying associative module is simply $e$ as an $e$-e-module, just as in Lemma 3.3.1, and so we have constructed a (unique) condensation bimodule extension. Similarly, the tensor product $e_{2} \otimes_{e_{2}} e \otimes_{e_{1}} e_{1}$ determines a condensation $e_{2}-e_{1}$-bimodule structure on $e$. Finally, the tensor products $\left(e_{2} \otimes_{e_{2}} e \otimes_{e_{1}} e_{1}\right) \otimes_{e_{1}}\left(e_{1} \otimes_{e_{1}} e \otimes_{e_{2}} e_{2}\right)$ and $\left(e_{1} \otimes_{e_{1}} e \otimes_{e_{2}} e_{2}\right) \otimes_{e_{2}}\left(e_{2} \otimes_{e_{2}} e \otimes_{e_{1}} e_{1}\right)$ are easily seen to be identities (since they are condensation bimodule extensions of $e$ to an $e_{1}-e_{1^{-}}$or $e_{2}-e_{2}$-bimodule, and such extension is unique).

A monoidal 1-category is called rigid if all its objects admit both left and right duals. We will call a monoidal $n$-category is 1-rigid if all its objects admit left and right duals. (Compare §4.1.) Combining Theorem 3.1.7 with Lemmas 3.3.1 and 3.3.2 gives:
Theorem 3.3.3. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a n-category such that all hom $(n-1)$-categories in $\mathcal{C}$ have all condensates and all endomorphism $(n-1)$-categories in $\mathcal{C}$ are 1-rigid. Then $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is equivalent to the ncategory $\mathcal{C}^{\vee}$ whose objects are separable monads in $\mathcal{C}$ and whose n-morphisms are bimodules in the associative unital sense.

Note that separable monads correspond to separable adjunctions, and so are automatically unital. The name $\mathcal{C}^{\vee}$ for the latter category comes from [DR18].

Proof. Let $\operatorname{Kar}^{\mathrm{un}}(\mathcal{C})$ denote the full sub- $n$-category of $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ on the objects represented by unital condensation monads. I.e. an object of $\operatorname{Kar}^{\mathrm{un}}(\mathcal{C})$ is a unital condensation monad, and a 1-morphism is a condensation bimodule. Under the condition that all endomorphism categories in $\mathcal{C}$ are rigid, Theorem 3.1.7 implies that the inclusion $\operatorname{Kar}^{\mathrm{un}}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is essentially surjective, and so an equivalence.

We will show that the forgetful functor $\operatorname{Kar}^{\mathrm{un}}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\vee}$ which forgets the comultiplication is also an equivalence. (That this functor is defined follows from Remark 3.1.6, which showed that condensation bimodules between unital condensation monads automatically respect the units.) It is essentially surjective by definition of $\mathcal{C}^{\vee}$, and so it suffices to show that $\operatorname{Kar}^{\mathrm{un}}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\vee}$ induces equivalences on hom categories, i.e. that, given unital condensation monads $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$, the forgetful functor $\{$ condensation $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodules $\} \rightarrow$ \{unital associative $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodules $\}$ is an equivalence. But suppose $m$ is a unital associative $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodule. Then, as in the proof of Lemma 3.3.1, construct the condensation bimodule $e_{1} \otimes_{e_{1}} m \otimes_{e_{2}} e_{2}$. Because $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ are unital, this tensor product is isomorphic (as a unital associative bimodule) to $m$. Thus the functor $m \mapsto e_{1} \otimes_{e_{1}} m \otimes_{e_{2}} e_{2}$ is an inverse to the forgetful functor $\{$ condensation $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodules $\} \rightarrow$ \{unital associative $e_{1}-e_{2}$ bimodules $\}$, completing the proof.

Recall from Example 2.3.13 that, for a symmetric monoidal $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$, there is a natural symmetric monoidal $(n+1)$-category $\Sigma \mathcal{C}=\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C})$ and an equivalence $\mathcal{C} \cong \Omega \Sigma \mathcal{C}:=\operatorname{End}_{\Sigma \mathcal{C}}(1)$.

Corollary 3.3.4. Let Vec denote the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces over a field $\mathbb{K}$. Then $\Sigma$ Vec is equivalent to the 2-category whose objects are finite-dimensional separable unital associative $\mathbb{K}$-algebras, whose 1-morphisms are finite-dimensional (unital associative) bimodules, and whose 2-morphisms are homomorphisms of bimodules.

We expect essentially the same result one dimension up, but we did not check the details:
Conjecture 3.3.5. $\Sigma^{2} \mathbf{V e c}$ is equivalent to the 3-category, studied in [DSPS13, DSPS19], whose objects are separable finite tensor categories and whose 1-morphisms are their separable bimodule categories.

Over a field of characteristic zero, the separable finite tensor categories are precisely the multifusion (i.e. semisimple tensor) categories, and a bimodule category is separable if and only if it is semisimple.

# 4. Absolute limits and full dualizability 

The goal of this final section is to generalize to $n$-categories the following two well-known results about Karoubi envelopes of 1-categories:
(1) If $\mathcal{C}$ is a 1 -category, then $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is the closure of $\mathcal{C}$ under absolute limits, also called the Cauchy completion of $\mathcal{C}$. (A limit is absolute if limits of that shape are preserved by arbitrary functors.)
(2) Given a commutative ring $R$, denote by $\operatorname{Mat}(R)$ the category of finitely generated free $R$-modules. Then $\operatorname{Kar}(\operatorname{Mat}(R))$ is naturally equivalent to the category of dualizable $R$ modules.
By generalizing (1) to $n$-categories, we fully justify condensations as the "correct" categorification of split surjections. By generalizing (2) we complete our comparison between gapped phases of matter and TQFTs.
4.1. Full dualizability. The following notions are by now quite standard in higher category theory. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $n$-category and $f: X \rightarrow Y$ a $k$-morphism. A right adjoint of $f$ is a morphism

$f^{R}: Y \rightarrow X$ together with unit and counit $(k+1)$-morphisms $\eta: \operatorname{id}_{X} \Rightarrow f^{R} f$ and $\epsilon: f f^{R} \Rightarrow \mathrm{id}_{Y}$ such that the "zig-zag" compositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f \stackrel{f \eta}{\Longrightarrow} f f^{R} f \stackrel{\epsilon f}{\Longrightarrow} f, \\
& f^{R} \stackrel{\eta f^{R}}{\Longrightarrow} f^{R} f f^{R} \stackrel{f^{R} \epsilon}{\Longrightarrow} f^{R},
\end{aligned}
$$

are identities. Similarly, a left adjoint of $f$ is a morphism $f^{L}: Y \rightarrow X$ together with $(k+1)$ morphisms $\eta: \operatorname{id}_{Y} \Rightarrow f f^{L}$ and $\epsilon: f^{L} f \Rightarrow \operatorname{id}_{X}$ such that the "zig-zag" compositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f \stackrel{\eta f}{\Longrightarrow} f f^{L} f \stackrel{f \epsilon}{\Longrightarrow} f, \\
& f^{L} \stackrel{f^{L} \eta}{\Longrightarrow} f^{L} f f^{L} \stackrel{\epsilon f^{L}}{\Longrightarrow} f^{L},
\end{aligned}
$$

are identities.
Remark 4.1.1. There are various, ultimately equivalent, ways to implement the above definition, and in particular to interpret the phrase "such that (.. ) are identities," in higher categories. The version of adjunction given in [Lur09, Definition 2.3.13] simply asks for the existence of equivalences between the given compositions and the appropriate identities - in other words, in this version the adjoints $f^{R}$ and $f^{L}$ of $f$ are defined in terms of the homotopy bicategory of $\mathcal{C}$. (In fact, to show adjunctibility, it suffices to work in the gauntification of the homotopy bicategory of $\mathcal{C}$ [JFS17, Lemma 7.9].)

A fully coherent theory of adjunction is given in [RV16]. The desideratum for a fully coherent theory is that the following well-known fact from 2-categories should remain true: if a left or right adjoint exists, then it should be unique up to a contractible space of choices.
