One way to achieve this is to ask, when witnessing a right adjoint $f^{R}$ to $f$, for the data of an equivalence $(\epsilon f) \circ(f \eta) \stackrel{\circ}{\Rightarrow} \mathrm{id}_{f}$ while asking $\left(f^{R} \epsilon\right) \circ\left(\eta f^{R}\right)$ to have the property of being equivalent to an identity. Or one can ask to supply both equivalences, but then one must also supply further coherence data relating them.

It can happen that both $f^{L}$ and $f^{R}$ exist but that they are not isomorphic; even if they are isomorphic, it can happen that there is not a canonical isomorphism. Clearly $\left(f^{L}\right)^{R}=\left(f^{R}\right)^{L}=f$. The notation " $f \dashv f^{R}$ " means " $f^{R}$ is a right adjoint to $f$." If $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ both admit right adjoints, then the mate of a $(k+1)$-morphism $\phi: f \Rightarrow g$ is the composition

$$
g^{R} \stackrel{\eta_{f} g^{R}}{\Longrightarrow} f^{R} f g^{R} \stackrel{f^{R} \phi g^{R}}{\Longrightarrow} f^{R} g g^{R} \stackrel{f^{R} \epsilon_{g}}{\Longrightarrow} f^{R}
$$

where $\eta_{f}$ is the unit of the adjunction $f \dashv f^{R}$ and $\epsilon_{g}$ is the counit of the adjunction $g \dashv g^{R}$.
Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is a monoidal $n$-category. The left and right duals to an object $X \in \mathcal{C}$, if they exist, are the left and right adjoints to $X$ thought of as a 1-morphism in the one-object $(n+1)$ category $\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C}$. A monoidal 1-category is traditionally called rigid if all objects admit both left and right duals. Extending this notation, we will say that an $(n+1)$-category is $m$-rigid if all $k$-morphisms with $1 \leq k \leq m$ admit both left and right adjoints. A monoidal $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is $m$-rigid if the $n$-category $\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C}$ is $m$-rigid, i.e. if all $k$-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$ with $0 \leq k<m$ admit (duals or) adjoints. An $(n+1)$-category or monoidal $n$-category is fully rigid if it is $n$-rigid, this being the maximal amount of rigidity a nontrivial $(n+1)$-category may enjoy - an $(n+1)$-category is $(n+1)$-rigid if and only if all morphisms are invertible.

Theorem 4.1.2. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $(n+1)$-category all of whose hom-n-categories have all condensates. If $\mathcal{C}$ is m-rigid, then so is $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. In particular, if $\mathcal{C}$ is a fully rigid symmetric monoidal n-category with all condensates, then the symmetric monoidal $(n+1)$-category $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$ is also fully rigid.

Proof. Corollary 4.2.3, which we will prove independently, implies that for any symmetric monoidal $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ with all condensates, every object in $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$ is 1-dualizable. (The dual to a condensation algebra in $\mathcal{C}$ is its "opposite" condensation algebra.) The second sentence of the Theorem follows

from this together with the first sentence: if $\mathcal{C}$ is a fully rigid symmetric monoidal $n$-category, then $\mathrm{BC}$ is a fully rigid symmetric monoidal $(n+1)$-category (and so all $k$-morphisms with $k \geq 1$ admit adjoints).

We now turn to the first sentence of the Theorem. The main thing to show is that if $\mathcal{C}$ is 1-rigid, then so is $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. Suppose that $Y_{1} \stackrel{\mu}{\leftarrow} Y_{2}$ is a 1-morphism in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$; we wish to construct its right adjoint $\mu^{R}$ (an analogous construction provides its left adjoint). By Theorem 3.1.7, we may represent $Y_{1}$ by a unital condensation monad $\left(X_{1}, e_{1}, \ldots\right)$ in $\mathcal{C}$, and we may represent $Y_{2}$ by a counital condensation monad $\left(X_{2}, e_{2}, \ldots\right)$ in $\mathcal{C}$; with these choices made, $\mu$ will then be represented by an $e_{1}-e_{2}$-bimodule $m$. Let $f_{i}, g_{i}$ be the 1-morphisms in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ presenting $Y_{i}$ as the condensate of $\left(X_{i}, e_{i}, \ldots\right)$. The underlying 1-morphism of $m$ is $g_{1} \mu f_{2}$. Furthermore, we have the following adjoint pairs in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ :

$$
f_{1} \dashv g_{1}, \quad g_{2} \dashv f_{2}, \quad m \dashv m^{R}
$$

Including the morphism $m^{R}$ into diagram $(*)$, we find in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ :
![img-22.jpeg](img-22.jpeg)

The $\Rightarrow$ s stand in for both the units and counits of the various adjunctions.
By construction, $f_{1} m g_{2}=f_{1} g_{1} \mu f_{1} g_{2}$ carries two commuting condensation monads, whose product is a condensation monad on $f_{1} m g_{2}$ with condensate $\mu$. By taking their mates, these determine commuting condensation monads supported by $\left(f_{1} m g_{2}\right)^{R}=g_{2}^{R} m^{R} f_{1}^{R}=f_{2} m^{R} g_{1}$. The condensate of their product is the right adjoint $\mu^{R}$ which we set out to construct.

Finally, we need to show that if $k$-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$ admit adjoints for $k \geq 2$, then so do $k$ morphisms in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. A $k$-morphism in $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ for $k \geq 2$ is a condensation bimodule morphism, which is a type of $(k-1)$-morphism in the category of functors from the walking condensation bimodule to $\mathcal{C}$, which is a condensation bimodule in the category of $(k-1)$-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$. Thus the claim follows from what we have already proven because $k$-rigidity of $\mathcal{C}$ implies 1-rigidity of the category of $(k-1)$-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$. (Compare [JFS17, Section 7], where dualizability and adjunctibility questions in categories of morphisms are studied in detail. Alternately, note that the right adjoint to any type of bimodule morphism is, by standard general nonsense, automatically a "lax bimodule morphism" in the sense that compatibility between the (co)actions and the morphism holds only up to not-necessarily-invertible higher morphisms; but in the presence of sufficient rigidity, lax bimodule morphisms are automatically strong [DSPS19, Lemma 2.10].)

By appealing to the Cobordism Hypothesis [BD95, Lur09], we find:
Corollary 4.1.3. Each object of $\Sigma^{d} \mathbf{V e c}_{\mathbb{C}}$ determines a $(d+1)$-dimensional framed extended TQFT. Each $k$-morphism determines a codimension- $k$ defect (aka domain wall; see [Lur09, Example 4.3.23]) between framed extended TQFTs. The same statement holds with $\mathbf{V e c}_{\mathbb{C}}$ replaced by $\mathbf{S V e c}_{\mathbb{C}}$, $\operatorname{Rep}(G)$, etc.

Together with Theorem 2.4.4, we find a very tight relationship between TQFTs and gapped condensed matter systems.
4.2. Absolute colimits. The theory of (co)limits in $n$-categories is subtle [cM22], and much work remains to be done. Our understanding is that Markus Zetto is currently in the process of developing a rigorous theory of absolute higher (co)limits; Zetto plans to rigorously prove the results sketched below, whereas we will take some assumptions about higher colimits for granted.

The Yoneda embedding presents $\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ as the universal closure of $\mathcal{C}$ under colimits. Specifically, $\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ contains all colimits, and if $\mathcal{D}$ is any category containing all colimits, then functors $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ can be identified with colimit-preserving functors $\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$, where the identification takes the colimit-preserving functor $F: \operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ to the functor $F \circ \dot{x}: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$
(2) A presheaf $S \in \operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ is called tiny if the functor $\operatorname{hom}(S,-): \operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$ preserves all colimits. (The name is due to [BCJF15], based on various "small object" notions in the category-theory literature.) The image of $\dot{x}$ consists entirely of tiny objects, because if $\left(T_{i}, \ldots\right)$ describes a colimit in $\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$, then one can show directly that the presheaf $C \mapsto \operatorname{colim}\left(T_{i}(C), \ldots\right)$ is its colimit.

Write $\operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$ for the full sub-n-category of $\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ on the tiny objects. Then $\operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$ is the universal closure of $\mathcal{C}$ under absolute colimits in the sense that if $\mathcal{D}$ is any $n$-category containing all absolute colimits, then functors $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ and functors $\operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ are naturally identified. The $n$-category $\operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$ is called the Cauchy completion of $\mathcal{C}$. (The name is due to [Law73] and is based on an analogy between enriched categories and metric spaces.)
Even without a complete description of $n$-categorical colimits, we claim:
Theorem 4.2.2. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an n-category all of whose hom- $(n-1)$-categories have all condensates. Then $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ and $\operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$ agree.

Proof. As mentioned already in Example 4.2.1, taking the condensate of a condensation monad is an example of an absolute colimit. Abstract nonsense then provides a fully faithful inclusion $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$. For definiteness, we will describe this inclusion in detail. Consider $T \in \operatorname{Psh}(\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}))$ a presheaf on $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$. By construction, each object $Y \in \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ is the condensate of a condensation monad $(X, e, \ldots) \in \mathcal{C}$. Apply $T$ to this condensation $X \rightarrow Y$; the result is a condensation $T X \rightarrow T Y$ in $\mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$. By Theorem 2.3.2, this condensation, and in particular $T Y$, is determined by the condensation monad $(T X, T e, \ldots)$. Thus restriction along $\mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ gives a map $\operatorname{Psh}(\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})) \rightarrow \operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$, which is in fact an equivalence: $\mathbf{C a t}_{n-1}$ contains all condensates (Example 2.3.8), and so for any $T \in \operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ extends uniquely to a presheaf on $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$; the extension sends $Y=(X, e, \ldots) \in \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C})$ to the condensate of $(T X, T e, \ldots)$. But the Yoneda embedding $\dot{x}: \operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Psh}(\operatorname{Kar}(\mathcal{C}))=\operatorname{Psh}(\mathcal{C})$ takes values within the subcategory of tiny objects.

To establish the converse inclusion, we must show that for each tiny presheaf $S \in \operatorname{Cau}(\mathcal{C})$, there is a condensation $\dot{x}(C) \rightarrow S$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}$.

Every presheaf can be written as a colimit of (the images under $\dot{x}$ of) objects in $\mathcal{C}$ - this is part of the universality described in (1) above. The universal way to do this is as follows. The list of objects $X_{i}$ contains many copies of $\dot{x}(C)$ for each $C \in \mathcal{C}$, one copy for each element $f \in \operatorname{hom}(\dot{x}(C), S)=S(C)$; the map $x_{i}: X_{i} \rightarrow S$ is this $f: \dot{x}(C) \rightarrow S$. For the 1-morphisms, one runs through all 1-morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$ and also all 1-morphisms in the various $S(C)$ s. Etcetera. Let us simply write $\mathcal{X}=\left(X_{i}, \ldots\right)$ for this list of data, so that $S=\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{X}$.

Now we use that $S$ is tiny. Then in particular $\operatorname{hom}(S,-)$ preserves the colimit of shape $\mathcal{X}$ :

$$
\operatorname{hom}(S, S)=\operatorname{hom}(S, \operatorname{colim} \mathcal{X})=\operatorname{colim} \operatorname{hom}(S, \mathcal{X})
$$

(As with elsewhere in this paper, the symbol " $=$ " does not mean equality of $(n-1)$-categories, but rather the presence of a canonical equivalence.)

What is colim hom $(S, \mathcal{X})$; in particular, what are its objects? It is a colimit of $(n-1)$-categories. So let us consider some generic colimit of $(n-1)$-categories, described by some list of data $\mathcal{Y}=$ $\left(Y_{i}, \ldots\right)$. Then each $Y_{i}$ on the list is itself an $(n-1)$-category with a map to colim $\mathcal{Y}$, and so the objects of the $Y_{i} \mathrm{~s}$ provide objects of the colimit. These are not necessarily all of the objects of colim $\mathcal{Y}$, as illustrated by Example 4.2.1: the objects of the condensate are the condensation modules, and not all modules are free. Rather, by unpacking the defining property of the colimit, one finds that every object in colim $\mathcal{Y}$ is an absolute (!) colimit of objects in the image of the $Y_{i} \mathrm{~s}$.

(Not all absolute such colimits need to exist in colim $\mathcal{Y}$.) These are absolute colimits inside an $(n-1)$-category, and so by induction are simply condensations: for each each object in colim $\mathcal{Y}$, there is an object in some $Y_{i}$ condensing to it.

In particular, the identity map $\operatorname{id}_{S} \in \operatorname{hom}(S, S)$ must arise as the condensation of some object in some $\operatorname{hom}\left(S, X_{i}\right)$. Unpacked, this means that there is some pair $X_{i}=(C, f)$ with $C \in \mathcal{C}$ and $f: \varkappa(C) \rightarrow S$, and some element $g \in \operatorname{hom}(S, \varkappa(C))$, such that the element $f g \in \operatorname{hom}(S, S)$ condenses to $\operatorname{id}_{S}$. Thus $\varkappa(C) \rightarrow S$.

Recall that, if $\mathcal{C}$ is a monoidal $n$-category, then a $\mathcal{C}$-module $n$-category is a module object for $\mathcal{C}$ understood as an algebra object in the symmetric monoidal $(n+1)$-category $\mathbf{C a t}_{n}$. Equivalently, a $\mathcal{C}$-module $n$-category is a functor of $(n+1)$-categories $\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathbf{C a t}_{n}$. If $\mathcal{C}$ is symmetric monoidal, then so is $\operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})$. (The tensor product is defined by a certain colimit in the $(\infty, 1)$-category underlying $\mathbf{C a t}_{n}$ that we will not recall, and relies on the fact that, as an $(\infty, 1)$-category, $\mathbf{C a t}_{n}$ contains all colimits and is Cartesian closed.)

Corollary 4.2.3. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a symmetric monoidal $n$-category with all condensates. Let $\operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})$ denote the symmetric monoidal $(n+1)$-category of all $\mathcal{C}$-module $n$-categories. Its full subcategory on the 1-dualizable objects is equivalent to $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$.

Proof. By definition, $\operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})=\operatorname{Psh}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C})$. By Theorem 4.2.2, $\Sigma \mathcal{C}=\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C})$ is the full sub- $(n+1)$ category of $\operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})$ on the tiny objects. In any category of modules, an object is tiny if and only if it is 1-dualizable. In one direction, if $M \in \operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})$ has a dual module $M^{*}$, then $\operatorname{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(M,-)$ is equivalent to $M^{*} \otimes_{\mathcal{C}}(-)$ and so preserves colimits. In the other direction, if $M$ is tiny, then $M^{*}=\operatorname{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(M, \mathcal{C})$ is its dual object: the functors $\operatorname{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(M,-)$ and $M^{*} \otimes_{\mathcal{C}}(-)$ take the same value on $\mathcal{C} \in \operatorname{Mod}(\mathcal{C})$ and both preserve colimits, and so agree.

Combined with Theorem 4.1.2, we learn the following remarkable fact, generalizing the characterization of 1-dualizable linear categories from [Til98, Section 2]:

Corollary 4.2.4. Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is a fully-rigid symmetric monoidal $n$-category with all condensates. Then a $\mathcal{C}$-module $n$-category is 1-dualizable if and only if it is fully-dualizable.
4.3. Direct sums and additive $n$-categories. Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is a higher category equipped with some notion of "addition" of 1-morphism. A direct sum of objects $X, Y \in \mathcal{C}$ is an object $X \oplus Y$ equipped with maps

$$
f_{X}: X \oplus Y \rightarrow X, \quad f_{Y}: X \oplus Y \rightarrow Y, \quad g_{X}: X \rightarrow X \oplus Y, \quad g_{Y}: Y \rightarrow X \oplus Y
$$

such that

$$
g_{X} f_{X}+g_{Y} f_{Y} \cong \operatorname{id}_{X \oplus Y}, \quad f_{A} g_{B} \cong \begin{cases}\operatorname{id}_{A}, & A=B \\ 0, & A \neq B\end{cases}
$$

Such $X \oplus Y$ is then both the product and coproduct of $X$ with $Y$. The category $\mathcal{C}$ has direct sums if it has a zero object - an object $0 \in \mathcal{C}$ such that $\mathrm{id}_{0}=0$ - and if every pair of objects $X, Y$ admits a direct sum $X \oplus Y$.

Remark 4.3.1. Our discussion is intentionally slightly sloppy about the difference, vital in higher category theory, between data and property. Specifically, should the choice of isomorphism be part of the data of the direct sum? The answer is that if all isomorphisms $g_{X} f_{X}+g_{Y} f_{Y} \cong \operatorname{id}_{X \oplus Y}$, $f_{X} g_{X} \cong \operatorname{id}_{X}$, etc., are part of the data of $X \oplus Y$, then one should also include higher coherence data relating these choices of isomorphisms. A more compact option is to judiciously choose some of the isomorphisms as data, and declare the existence of the others as property.

Direct sum is itself a form of "addition." As such, the most natural way for an $n$-category, with $n \geq 2$, to have an "addition" on 1-morphisms is if it has an addition on 2-morphisms and the addition on 1-morphisms is declared to be the direct sum of 1-morphisms. One is led naturally

to the following notion. An $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category is an $n$-category such that the sets of $n$ morphisms (recall from the start of Section 2 that we work with "weak $n$-" rather than " $(\infty, n)$-" categories, so that $n$-morphisms do form sets) are given the structure of abelian groups, and such that all compositions are multilinear on $n$-morphisms. The abelian group structure on $n$-morphisms determines a notion of direct sum on $(n-1)$-morphisms, which determines a notion of direct sum on $(n-2)$-morphisms, all the way to objects. An additive $n$-category is an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category which has direct sums at all levels.
Lemma 4.3.2. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a monoidal additive $(n-1)$-category with condensates and direct sums. Then $\Sigma \mathcal{C}=\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C})$, which is by construction an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category with condensates, also has direct sums.

Proof. Suppose objects $A, B \in \Sigma \mathcal{C}$ are represented by condensation algebras, also denoted $A$ and $B$, in $\mathcal{C}$. Then the direct sum $A \oplus B$ in $\mathcal{C}$ carries a distinguished condensation algebra structure, and it represents the direct sum of objects in $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$.

Lemma 4.3.2 relies on the fact that $B \mathcal{C}$ has only one object. If it were replaced by an $n$ category with multiple objects, then condensation monads living at different objects would not be direct-summable in the Karoubi completion. Instead, their direct sum must be included by hand. In general, suppose $\mathcal{C}$ is an additive $n$-category whose hom $(n-1)$-categories have direct sums. The matrix category of $\mathcal{C}$, denoted $\operatorname{Mat}(\mathcal{C})$, is the $n$-category whose objects are vectors (i.e. finite sequences) of objects in $\mathcal{C}$, and whose morphisms are matrices of morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$. The matrix category is precisely the closure of $\mathcal{C}$ under direct sums. It is not hard to show furthermore that $\operatorname{Kar}(\operatorname{Mat}(\mathcal{C}))$ has direct sums, and so the combination Kar $\circ$ Mat is the closure under both direct sums and condensates.

Indeed, the results of $\S 4.2$ apply essentially verbatim in the additive world, provided Kar is replaced by Kar $\circ$ Mat. Indeed, an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category is nothing but an $(\infty, 1)$-category enriched, in the $(\infty, 1)$-sense, in $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $(n-1)$-categories, and so the eventual development of a theory of enriched colimits in the $(\infty, 1)$-world will include the case of colimits in $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-categories. Ab-enriched colimits include colimits, but one may also add $k$-morphisms together when giving the data $\mathcal{X}$; an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched colimit is absolute if it is preserved by all $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched functors.

Example 4.3.3. Finite direct sums are $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched-absolute.
$\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $(n-1)$-categories naturally form an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category $\mathbf{A b C a t}{ }_{n-1}$, and an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched presheaf on an $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is a functor of $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-categories $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathbf{A b C a t}{ }_{n-1}$. The $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-category of $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched presheaves will be the universal closure under $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched colimits. It still makes sense to talk about tiny objects and the Cauchy completion: in the $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched world, an object $S$ is tiny if the $\mathbf{A b C a t}{ }_{n-1}$-valued functor $\operatorname{hom}(S,-)$ preserves colimits.

To modify Theorem 4.2.2 to the $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched setting, one must make only one change: when studying a colimit colim $\mathcal{Y}$ of $(n-1)$-categories, in the $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched case the objects of the colimit are absolute-in-the- $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched-sense objects in the image of the $Y_{i} \mathrm{~s}$, and so by induction are condensations of direct sums, rather than merely condensations. From this, one finds $\mathrm{id}_{S}$ as a condensation of a direct sum of objects in $\mathcal{C}$. Thus:
Theorem 4.3.4. The Cauchy completion among $\mathbf{A b}$-enriched $n$-categories is $\operatorname{Kar}(\operatorname{Mat}(-))$.
Finally, in light of Lemma 4.3.2, we recommend the following notation. Suppose $\mathcal{C}$ is monoidal with a notion of addition which may not be the direct sum. Then $\Sigma \mathcal{C}$ will mean $\operatorname{Kar}(\operatorname{Mat}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C}))$ rather than merely $\operatorname{Kar}(\mathrm{B} \mathcal{C})$. For additive $n$-categories, this meaning of $\Sigma$ agrees with our earlier meaning except when $n=0$. An additive 0 -category is an abelian group, and a monoidal additive 0 -category is a ring $R$, in which case $\Sigma R=\operatorname{Kar}(\operatorname{Mat}(\mathrm{B} R))$ is precisely the category of finitely

generated projective $R$-modules. With this notation, Corollaries 4.2.3 and 4.2.4, and their proofs, apply verbatim with the words "additive" included, even when $n=0$.

Example 4.3.5. If $\mathbb{K}$ is a field, then $\operatorname{Vec}_{\mathbb{K}} \simeq \Sigma \mathbb{K}$, where as always in this paper " $\operatorname{Vec}_{\mathbb{K}}$ " means the category of finite-dimensional and $\Sigma \mathbb{K}$ means the additive version. Then Corollary 4.1.3 could be phrased as "Each object of $\Sigma^{n} \mathbb{C}$ determines an $n$-dimensional extended TQFT," and Theorem 2.4.4 could be phrased as "Each object of $\Sigma^{n} \mathbb{C}$ determines an $n$-dimensional commuting projector Hamiltonian system," where in both cases $n=(n-1)+1$ is the spacetime dimension. Corollaries 4.2.3 and 4.2.4, when applied to $\mathcal{C}=\Sigma^{n} \mathbb{K}$, say that a $\mathbb{K}$-linear $n$-category is 1 -dualizable, in the $(n+1)$ category of all Cauchy-complete $\mathbb{K}$-linear $n$-categories, if and only if it is fully dualizale, and that the $(n+1)$-category of dualizable $\mathbb{K}$-linear $n$-categories is precisely to $\Sigma^{n+1} \mathbb{K}$.
